poem:
"A Tale in Tudor Tapestries"

Behind the framework of an ancient year,
Three women, under cover of Tudor drapes,
Chase echoes of a fearful tale, replete with cheer.
Their whispers bloom like marigolds, into shapes - 
Script of friendship, in its grandest display,
Beneath the shadow of Boleyn's mournful day.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Ava Pickett’s drama of female friendship in Tudor England wins Susan Smith Blackburn prize The British playwright Ava Pickett has won this year’s Susan Smith Blackburn prize for female, transgender and non-binary playwrights. Pickett’s winning play, 1536, unfolds in Tudor Essex and follows three women as they discuss the news of Anne Boleyn’s arrest. Pickett called it a “very funny and very angry play” about female friendship. In a ceremony at the Royal Court theatre". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
